repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Technical Education and Training
            Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Technical Education and Training
            Modernization Project for Mexico had the following ratings:
            the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was
            likely, the institutional development impact was modest, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory.
            The lessons learned indicate that unexperienced Bank and
            Borrower preparation teams defining an innovative project in
            uncharted territory involving two Ministries (Education and
            Labor) led to a very complex design. Investments that cross
            over different sectors as well as different elected
            administrations run the risk of disenfranchisement by the
            incoming administration in some of the participating
            sectors. Successful projects are built on the foundation of
            previous, smaller scale interventions. Effective
            supervisions, looking at both the substantive parts of the
            project as well as the fiduciary and governance aspects of
            implementation, are key instruments to continually improve
            the efficiency and effectiveness of project implementation.
            The early stages of Trust in Support of the System of
            Occupational Standards and Certification (CONOCER) where
            highly inefficient and costly as a result of its
            supply-driven and untargeted approach. The average
            certification cost will decrease as a function of
            decentralizing the 32 licensed certification units,
            currently all located in Mexico City. The competency-based
            scheme seems to work more effectively where there exists a
            clear articulation between the upper technical secondary
            (UTS) schools and the regional productive sectors,
            especially the private ones.
